Professor Keith Christian: If we could go in a time machine and go 100
years into the future, what do you think the

6.text:
field of evolutionary biology would be like?
Do you think they'll look back on 21st century

11.text:
scientists and shake their heads and say,
“Those guys really were going down the wrong

16.text:
track,” or do you think it'll be very different
at all?

19.text: Professor Rosemary Grant: Do you want to go first? Or shall I?

23.text:
Professor Peter Grant: I don't think that our successors will say
“Those guys really had got it wrong.”

29.text:
No, I think just as we look back 100 years
and say the foundations were laid correctly

36.text:
by theory and by observation and by experiment,
so I'm hoping that in 100 years’ time, they'll

43.text:
look back at our knowledge and say, “Well,
very incomplete, and they didn't know this

46.text:
and they didn't know that, but at least they
had the fundamentals correctly understood.”

52.text:
So what is likely to be the acquired knowledge
in the next 100 years? Science progresses

60.text:
in both predictable and unpredictable, certain
and uncertain ways, and one can easily identify

67.text:
some things which will be much better known
in the future, and yet there’s going to

71.text:
be many other things that we have no way of
accessing. So in the first category, I would

76.text:
think in terms of such things as complex phenomena
like brain structure and function, how the

85.text:
brain actually works. 84 billion neurons in
our brains – how is it all put together,

90.text:
and can we make evolutionary sense of the
wiring diagrams and the construct of our brain?

97.text:
Second one would be cancer. We don't know
- we know a lot about cancer, but we certainly

103.text:
don't know anywhere near enough, and it is
an evolutionary phenomenon in that cancer

108.text:
is within the body of an individual, an ongoing
evolutionary experiment of change – genetic

114.text:
change and then multiplication. Our successors
will know very much more about that. And then…

122.text:
we are already making discoveries that I think
will be greatly enhanced and amplified in

128.text:
the future on the origin of life. How life
actually began at one end – you might think

137.text:
of this as a spectrum of complexity – and
at the other end, our own evolution, where

143.text:
we came from, who our ancestors were. We’re
making discoveries in the field of palaeontology,

149.text:
which are really remarkable and are in the
“unpredictable” category. Who would've

155.text:
guessed that we would have found bones of
people that we now call “hobbits” from

159.text:
Flores Island in Indonesia, for example. If
anybody say, 50 years ago, had said “You

167.text:
know, one day you might find ancestors of
hominins who are not Neanderthals, but are

174.text:
somewhat similar and who branched off the
main line earlier” – we now call them

179.text:
denisovans. If somebody had said, “Now I
think there would be some discoveries of bones

185.text:
– maybe only fragmentary bones – that
will fill in the picture a little bit,”

190.text:
I don't think anybody at that time would have
said “Yes, and we'll have the molecular

194.text:
tool to be able to identify and age and characterise
the individual that gave rise to the bone,

204.text:
that had the bones, and put that individual
on the evolutionary tree of homosapiens.”

211.text:
These are the unexpected things, and there
must be a lot more of those yet down the road

217.text:
Professor Rosemary Grant: So I think one of the exciting areas that
will be explored is the evolutionary of consciousness,

226.text:
and also a much greater understanding of the
evolution of language. And here, I think we

233.text:
can go back to birds, because half the species
of birds in the world today learn their song,

240.text:
the other half are genetically determined.
Amongst the birds that learn the song, there’s

245.text:
some like Darwin's finches that learn them
in a short period of time, and there are others,

250.text:
that like us, will learn throughout life and
add to their repertoire throughout life. And

256.text:
then there are others where the song centres
disappear in the winter, and are sort of regrown

266.text:
again each spring. And so they sort of add
on or change the song each year. The song

270.text:
centres in the birds’ brain are very similar
to the song centres, or the speech centres,

275.text:
in the human brain – very similar to Broca's
and Wernicke's. We even have some of the same

281.text:
genes that are involved, like the FOXP2 gene
is involved. So these are just the beginning,

283.text:
and I think that in 100 years we'll know much
more about the origin of our language ability,

298.text:
and also much more about the evolution of
consciousness as well.

303.text:
Professor Keith Christian: Well, thank you very much, and I certainly
hope that both of you enjoy your time at Charles

310.text: Darwin University, and in the Northern Territory.

311.text: Professor Rosemary Grant: We definitely will! Thank you very much.

314.text: Professor Peter Grant: Thank you Keith, thank you.
